bioghist.p: Ching Chun Li (1912-2003) was a population geneticist. He received his bachelor's degree from the University of Nanking in 1936 and his Ph.D. from Cornell University in 1940. He was a professor at the University of Nanking (1943-1946) where he ran a contemporary and vigorous genetics research and training program. In 1946, he was named professor and chairman of Agronomy at the National Peking University (1946-1950). After the Communist Revolution in China, the genetic theories of Trofim Lysenko were held by the government to be the only ones compatible with dialectical materialism, and supporters of Mendel were severely repressed and sometimes even in physical danger. Li refused to follow the official policy and was forced to resign. He and his family fled China, arriving in Hong Kong in 1950. From there, he emigrated to the United States, where he was hired as a research fellow and assistant professor of biostatistics at the University of Pittsburgh. He remained at Pittsburgh for the remainder of his career, retiring in the early 1980s as professor emeritus. After his retirement, Li continued to work and publish papers.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the professional papers of Ching Chun Li. Materials include: correspondence in English and Chinese with colleagues, journal editors, and students; course materials; personnel files and recommendations; student dissertations; manuscripts and reprints by Li and others; drafts of articles; lecture and research notes; slides; correspondence related to peer reviews and reviewer comments; and photographs. The collection also contains correspondence (in Chinese) between Li and various researchers at Academia Sinica in Taiwan.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
